direction.raw_text: : SNOWFLAKES The flakes drift lazily down toward us. Our angle looks straight up. Now an angle looking steeply down: the snow falls not quite dead away to collect on a foreground chimneypot and on the little shtetl street that lies maplike below us. It is night, and quiet, and the street is deserted except for one man who walks away from us, his valenki squeaking in the fresh snow. He carries bundled branches on one shoulder and has a hatchet tucked into his belt. We cut down to street level. The man walks toward us, bearded, and bundled against the cold. Smiling, he mutters in Yiddish-the dialogue subtitled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a marvel... what a marvel...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As its door opens and the man enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dora!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes... The man crosses to the stove with his bundle of wood. The voice continues:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Can you help me with the ice? The man dumps the wood into a box by the stove as his wife enters with an ice pick. . I expected you hours ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't imagine what just happened. I was coming back on the Lublin road when the wheel came off the cart thank heavens it was the way back and I'd already sold the geese!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fifteen groshen, but that's not the story. I was struggling to set the cart upright when a droshky approaches from the direction of Lvov. How lucky, you think, that someone is out this late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, very remarkable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But that's the least of it! He stops to help me; we talk of this, we talk of that-it turns out this is someone you know! Traitle Groshkover! His wife stares at him as he beams. He takes the stare as a sign that she can't place the name. . You know, REB GROSHKOVER! Pesel Bunim's uncle! The chacham from Lodz, who studied under the Zohar reb in Krakow! Still she stares. Then, quietly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God has cursed us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Traitle Groshkover has been dead for three years. Laughter erupts from the man but, as his wife continues to stare at him, he strangles on it. Quiet. Wind whistles under the eaves. The man says quietly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you say such a thing! I saw the man! I talked to him!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You talked to a dybbuk. Traitle Groshkover died of typhus in Pesel Bunim's house. Pesel told me-she sat shiva for him. They stare at each through a silence broken only by the sound of the quickening wind. A rap at the door. Neither immediately responds. Finally, to her husband: Who is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For some soup, to warm himself. The wind moans. He helped me, Dora!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are looking in from the outside as it unlatches and creaks in, opened by the husband in the foreground, who has arranged his face into a strained look of greeting. In the background the wife stares, hollow-eyed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! You are welcome here! Reverse on REB GROSHKOVER: a short, merry-looking fellow with a bifurcated beard and a silk hat and spectacles. He gives a little squeal of delight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are too kind, Velvel! Too kind! He steps into the house and sees the wife staring at him. And you must be Dora! So much I have heard of you! Yes, your cheeks are pink and your legs are stout! What a wife you have! The husband chuckles nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes! A ray of sun, a ray of sun! Sit!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My husband said he offered you soup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, but I couldn't possibly eat this late, or I'd have nightmares. No, no: no soup for me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see! You think I'm fat enough already! He settles, chuckling, into his chair, but Dora remains sober:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. A dybbuk doesn't eat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at her, shocked. The wife returns the stare. The husband looks from wife to REB GROSHKOVER, apprehensive. A heavy silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: bursts into pealing laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a wife you have! He wipes away tears of merriment; the husband relaxes, even begins to smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I assure you, REB GROSHKOVER, it's nothing personal; she heard a story you had died, three years ago, at Pesel Bunim's house. This is why she think you are a dybbuk; I, of course, do not believe in such things. I am a rational man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is still chuckling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my. Oh my yes. What nonsense. And even if there were spirits, certainly... He thumps his chest. I am not one of them!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pesel always worried. Your corpse was left unattended for many minutes when Pesel's father broke shiva and left the room-it must have been then that the Evil One- She breaks off to spit at the mention of the Evil One. -took you!

direction.raw_text: is terribly amused:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "My corpse!" Honestly! What a wife you have!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes? Look, husband... She steps forward to the Reb, who looks enquiringly up at her. They were preparing the body. Pesel's father shaved one check... As his eyes roll down to look at her hand, she draws it across his smooth right cheek. Then he left the room. He came back, and shaved the other... She reaches across to the other cheek, REB GROSHKOVER's eyes following her hand- You were already gone! -and drags her hand across. A bristly sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I shaved hastily this morning and missed a bit-by you this makes me a dybbuk? He appeals to the husband: It's true, I was sick with typhus when I stayed with Peselle, but I recovered, as you can plainly see, and now I-hugh! The wife steps back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks slowly down at his own chest in which the wife has just planted an ice pick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at the ice pick. The wife stares.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The husband stares. Suddenly, REB GROSHKOVER bursts out laughing: What a wife you have! The husband can manage only a shocked whisper:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woman, what have you done?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: again looks down at his chest, which again moves him to laughter. He shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why would she do such a thing? He looks up. I ask you, Velvel, as a rational man: which of us is possessed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you say now about spirits? He is unharmed!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the contrary! I don't feel at all well. And indeed, blood has begun to soak through his vest. He chuckles with less energy. One does a mitzvah and this is the thanks one gets?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dora! Woe, woe! How can such a thing be!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps I will have some soup. I am feeling weak... He rises to his feet but totters. Or perhaps I should go...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles weakly at Dora.. One knows when one isn't wanted. He walks unsteadily to the door, opens it with some effort, and staggers out into the moaning wind and snow to be swallowed by the night. The wife and husband stare at the door banging in the wind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dear wife. We are ruined. Tomorrow they will discover the body. All is lost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nonsense, Velvel... She walks to the door... Blessed is the Lord. Good riddance to evil and shuts it against the wind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A drumbeat thumps in the black. Music blares: the Jefferson Airplane. Grace Slick's voice enters: When the truth is found to be lies And all the hope inside you dies Don't you want somebody to love. . . An image fades in slowly, but even up full it is dim: some kind of round, dull white shape with a small black pinhole center. This white half-globe is a plug set in a flesh-toned field. The flesh tone glows translucently, backlit. We are drifting toward the white plug and, as we do so, the music grows louder still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pull back-a reverse on the preceding push in-from the cheap white plastic earpiece of a transistor radio. The Jefferson Airplane continues over the cut but becomes extremely compressed. The pull back reveals that the earpiece is lodged in someone's ear and trails a white cord. We drift down the cord to find the radio at its other end. As we do so we hear, live in the room, many voices speaking a foreign language in unison. A classroom, apparently. The radio is on a desktop but hidden from in front by the book held open before it. The book is written in non-Roman characters. We are in Hebrew school. The boy who is listening to the transistor radio-DANNY Gopnik-sits at a hinge-topped desk in a cinderblock classroom whose rows of desks are occupied by other boys and girls of about twelve years of age. It is dusk and the room is flourescent-lit. At the front of the room a gray-haired man in a worn suit and tie addresses the class.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: straightens one leg so that he may dig into a pocket. With an eye on the TEACHER to make sure he isn't being watched, he eases something out: A twenty-dollar bill.

Fleshy whorls finely veined, a cavity receding to dark. Objective on the DOCTOR's office: the DOCTOR is peering through a lightscope into the ear of an early-middle-aged man, LARRY Gopnik. The Jefferson Airplane music continues.

Wider shows that the portrait hangs in the Hebrew school principal's office, a white cinderblock room. It is quiet. The only sound is a deep electrical hum. Just visible behind the principal's desk, upon which is a low stack of books and a name plate identifying the occupant as MAR TURCHIK, is the top of a man's head-an old man, with a few whispy white hairs where his yarmulka is not.

Close on his hairy, wrinkled ear as his trembling fingers bring in the earpiece. The i f ngers push and wobble and tamp the earpiece into place, hesitate, and then do some more pushing and wobbling and tamping. The principal keeps DANNY fixed with a stare as his hand hesitantly drops from his ear, ready to reach back up should the earpiece loosen. .mneh... Satisfied that neither the student nor the earpiece are about to make any sudden moves, he looks down at the radio. He turns a dial. Faintly and tinnily from the earpiece we hear the compressed jangle of rock music. The rabbi stares blankly, listening.

direction.raw_text: and Arthur are driving. We are looking at the two of them square through a windshield in which towering conifers stream by in reflection. It seems to be a glorious day.

direction.raw_text: waves. Arthur waves bravely back, then turns to pick up the oars. A couple of strokes and he turns back again with a last thought. He calls:

direction.raw_text: looks wildly around. He sees: Gar Brandt and Mitch in their camo fatigues, hard to pick out in the foliage. They are looking off toward the canoe, Mitch just lowering his rifle. Gar Brandt's look swings around, into the lens. He points at us: There's another Jew, son.

direction.raw_text: Mitch swings his rifle toward us. He fires.

direction.raw_text: Gasping awake in the motel room. He looks around. It is dawn. Arthur sits on the edge of his bed in his underwear, staring off into space, slackjawed, vacant-eyed, drained.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: gazes around the room, waiting for things to fall into place. Finally, blearily:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were we... out at the pool last night? Arthur, still staring off, responds in a flat, empty voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: blinks sleep away. After a beat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll go drain my cyst.

direction.raw_text: Day. A two-urinal, two-stall men's room of old tile and yellowed fixtures. We are low. One of the stall doors is closed. Under it we see the dress shoes and dress pants of two young men standing inside. We hear a long sucking inhale. Ronnie Nudell's Voice Gimme that fucker. A loudly projected echoing male voice:

direction.raw_text: Ya'amod hab'rayshit.

direction.raw_text: seated in the second pew next to his parents and sister and Uncle Arthur, rises and shuffles along the row to the aisle. His eyes are wide and red-rimmed. The prelapped voice was his call to the torah. All eyes in the congregation, which fills the large sanctuary, are on him. In great echoing silence he walks to the steps on the right side of the bema and climbs. The right-side lectern is surrounded by a gaggle of old Jewish men. They busy themselves with the preparation of the pair of scrolls on the lectern, rolling them, pausing, rolling some more, muttering prayers, kissing the scrolls by means of their tsitsim. They pay DANNY no attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: takes his place centered behind the lectern. His chin comes up to the bottom of the reading platform. Men continue to mutter prayers around him. A pair of hands appear on his shoulders from behind. DANNY looks down at the strange hands. They pull him back. A foot drags a small riser out from under the lectern. Hands push DANNY up onto the riser.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Booming up on the torah scrolls, still being busily rolled. Beyond it, a sea of faces. The yad-a molded tin pointer-is thrust into DANNY's hand. The non-pointing end has a red silken tassel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks at the bouncing tassel. He looks at the little pointing finger which is the business end of the yad. Men mutter around him, each a different prayer. They dip and doven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watches himself point the yad down at the scroll. The scroll is a dense swarm of Hebrew letters. DANNY squints. One voice separates from the murmurs around him. It chants, insistently, in a sotto-voce
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nefesh echad sheichayim, yitzeh gamor shel effashot...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is still staring at the end of the yad against the parchment scroll. Someone's hand enters and moves the yad to a different place in the text. The voice repeats: . Nefesh echad sheichayim, yitzeh gamor shel effashot...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks up from the scrolls. In the congregation Ronnie Nudell sits hunched-shouldered and squished between his parents. He returns DANNY's red-rimmed slack-jawed stare. The insistent voice: . Nefesh echad shelchayim, yitzeh gamor shel effashot...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks over. From the surrounding scrum the prompter nods at him. He looks somewhat like Cantor Youssele Rosenblatt.

direction.raw_text: . Nefesh echad shelchayim, yitzeh gamor shel effashot.. .

direction.raw_text: Nefesh echad shelchayim, yitzeh gamor shel effashot. .

direction.raw_text: continues to boom out the torah portion. He moves the yad along the line of letters. In the congregation, LARRY and Judith watch. We hear DANNY chanting fluently and

direction.raw_text: has been ensconced in a highbacked chair upstage on the bema. His point-of-view of the man holding the torah is close and steeply raked. The man is sweating. The heavy scrolls vibrate slightly from his effort to keep them aloft. As the congregation continues to sing he mutters under his breath:

And then you will be a member of B'Nai Abraham and of the Nation of Israel. DANNY Gopnik, the Sisterhood makes a gift to you of this kiddush cup so that you will remember this blessed day on the next shabbas and the next, and on every shabbas of a long and fruitful life, and, until that wonderful day when you stand under the chupa, we say.. .

direction.raw_text: still red-eyed, tries to focus. His point-of-view shows the kiddush cup large in the foreground, extended toward him by the Rabbi beaming above. His own hand rises into frame to grasp the kiddush cup. The congregation starts Adon Olam.

direction.raw_text: Creaking open. The cut has snapped off the robust Adon Olam, leaving sepulchral quiet.

direction.raw_text: clutching his kiddush cup, hesitantly enters the dim study. Minda's elderly eastern European gatekeeper closes the door behind him. Minda is an old man staring at him from behind a bare desktop. His look, eyes magnified by thick glasses, is impossible to read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: creeps to the chair facing the desk. He gingerly sits on the squeaking leather upholstery, self-conscious under Minda's stare. Minda breathes regularly through his mouth. It is the only sound in the room. A long beat. The two sit face to face. Minda smacks his lips a couple of times, preparing to speak. Another beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When the truth is found. To be lies. He pauses. He clears his throat. At length: . And all the hope. Within you dies. Another beat. DANNY waits. Minda stares. He smacks his lips again. . Then what?

direction.raw_text: doesn't answer. It is unclear whether the question was directed at him. Quiet.

direction.raw_text: Minda clears his throat with a loud and thorough hawking. The hawking abates. Minda sniffs. . Grace Slick. Marty Balin. Paul Kanta. Jorma... somethin. These are the membas of the Airplane. He nods a couple of times. . Interesting. He reaches up and slowly opens his desk drawer. He takes something out. direction.raw_text: He is staring down at his desktop. Thunder. He reaches up and scratches his nose as he stares at his desk. On the desk: a ledger sheet with a list of students' names. Next to each name, a grade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: drums his fingers. He picks up a pencil. He goes down to PARK, CLIVE. Next to it is an F. He waggles the pencil, eraser-end thumping the sheet. He erases the F. He enters a C. The pencil leaves frame. We hold for a beat on the new grade. The hand reenters. It puts a minus sign after the C. The hand withdraws.

direction.raw_text: still has his radio with the earpiece in. Everyone's clothing flaps. Ronnie Nudell shouts above the wind: Ronnie Nudell That fucking flag is gonna rip right off the flagpole!

direction.raw_text: We are looking through a windshield lashed by rain at LARRY, driving. His hands are clenched tight on the wheel. Wipers pump to keep up with the rain. The cars behind have their lights on. It has gotten quite dark. Passing streetlights rhythmically sweep LARRY's face, their light stippled and bent by the rain on the windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is looking across the lot in which orange school busses are parked. His head bobs in time to the music. His hair whips in the wind. A building roar, very deep.
